title: RL32541
content: The 9/11 Commission found that al Qaeda terrorists exploited weaknesses in aviation security, including a focus on potential bombers, lax checkpoint screening, lack of in-flight security measures, compliance with hijackers, and a failure of imagination among senior officials. The 9/11 Commission found that vulnerabilities in the aviation system were due to a failure of imagination among senior policymakers and agencies responsible for intelligence, national defense, and aviation security. Before September 11, 2001, there were no specific actions taken to defend against the possibility of suicide hijackings, which were greatly underestimated. Congressional oversight of aviation security was lacking, with a focus on airport congestion and passenger service. After the 9/11 attacks, Congress passed the Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) to address weaknesses in aviation security. ATSA established the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to oversee security in all modes of transportation, including establishing a federal security screener workforce. The Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) established TSA to oversee security in all transportation modes, focusing on aviation. It required explosive detection screening of checked bags, air marshals on high-risk flights, and hardened cockpit doors. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 placed TSA within the Department of Homeland Security and authorized arming airline pilots for additional security. Additional measures were included in the FAA reauthorization act, Vision 100 - Century. Vision 100 established an aviation security capital fund for explosive detection systems and arming pilots. However, vulnerabilities in air cargo operations, general aviation, employee access controls, screener performance, and potential terrorist attacks with shoulder-fired missiles persist. The 9/11 Commission also highlighted these vulnerabilities. The 9/11 Commission identified vulnerabilities in cargo and general aviation security, as well as inadequate screening and access controls. Recommendations were made for improvements in airport passenger and baggage screening, and air cargo security. The Commission did not address risks related to access controls in secured areas or shoulder-fired missile attacks against commercial airliners. The recommendations were outlined in a section titled "A Layered Security System." The 9/11 Commission emphasized the need for a multi-layered aviation security system that includes effective and coordinated security measures to address possible terrorist tactics. Recommendations focused on persisting vulnerabilities in commercial aviation, with a concept of "concentric rings of security." The 9/11 Commission's final report included six aviation-specific recommendations to enhance passenger pre-screening, improve explosives detection, address human factors at screening checkpoints, deploy baggage screening systems, intensify efforts to screen dangerous cargo, and use hardened cargo containers on passenger aircraft. Additionally, an overarching recommendation was made to prioritize transportation security based on risk and implement cost-effective deterrents. On September 11, 2001, passenger pre-screening involved three measures. Passenger pre-screening on September 11, 2001 involved three measures: CAPPS, security questions, and photo ID presentation. Over half of the hijackers were identified through these techniques, but with little consequence. CAPPS now screens for possible hijackers using behavioral algorithms. The CAPPS II system aims to authenticate passengers' identities and check them against terrorist watch lists for improved pre-screening capabilities, recommended by the 9/11 Commission. The system could deny boarding or require secondary screening for flagged passengers. The system has faced controversy over data privacy and civil liberties concerns. The Homeland Security Appropriations Act and Vision 100 directed the Department of Homeland Security to address concerns with CAPPS II implementation. The TSA only addressed one of eight concerns, and airlines' reluctance to provide data has hindered progress. Recent reports suggest that the CAPPS II program has been scrapped due to privacy concerns, but a new program may be developed in the future. Security Tom Ridge has suggested a new program may replace CAPPS II. Congress may increase oversight of the Secure Flight program, successor to CAPPS, and debate on implementation. Ramzi Yousef's 1994 bombing of a Philippines Airlines flight was a precursor to the "Bojinka" plot to bomb multiple U.S.-bound airliners. The TSA's approach of reimbursing airports for expenses as they are incurred could further slow down the integration of EDS systems at airports. The 9/11 Commission recommended that the aviation industry should pay a fair share of the costs for in-line EDS deployment, which has been a point of contention. Airlines and airports currently contribute to the costs, with airports facing proposed increases in their share. The 9/11 Commission recommended a more equitable contribution from the aviation industry for in-line EDS deployment. Congress is debating the cost-sharing equity for airport security projects, with proposed legislation seeking to increase aviation security fees for capital funds and TSA flexibility. H.R. 5121 aims to enhance TSA's flexibility in meeting checked baggage security screening requirements through multi-year contracts with airports or third-party vendors for EDS imaging capabilities. The TSA unveiled a strategic plan for cargo security in November 2003, based on recommendations from the Aviation Security Advisory Committee, focusing on enhancing shipper and supply chain security and identifying elevated risks. The TSA unveiled a strategic plan for cargo security in November 2003, focusing on key strategic objectives such as enhancing shipper and supply chain security, identifying elevated risk cargo through pre-screening, and securing all-cargo aircraft through appropriate facility security measures. The plan aims to pre-screen all cargo shipments, inspect items considered to pose an elevated risk, deploy new technology solutions, and implement operational and regulatory programs to support enhanced security measures. The 9/11 Commission recommendations support TSA's approach but suggest accelerating progress towards achieving these objectives. Recent debate in Congress over air cargo security has focused on the level of physical screening or inspection of cargo needed to mitigate risks. Proposals have been made to require 100% screening, but Congress has supported a risk-based approach relying on the known-shipper program. Both H.R. 10 and S. 2845 aim to improve cargo screening and tracking, with S. 2845 specifically requiring TSA to double the amount of air cargo screening. S. 2845 would require TSA to double air cargo screening within one year. The 9/11 Commission recommended deploying hardened cargo containers on passenger aircraft carrying suspicious cargo. The cost of acquiring these containers would be $125 million, with an estimated annual industry-wide cost of $11 million due to reduced revenue and increased fuel burn. Passenger airlines may oppose this initiative due to increased operational costs. Proponents of deploying hardened cargo containers argue that it adds a redundant layer of defense, similar to a hardened cockpit door, in line with the goal of a multi-layered security system. However, using just one container per passenger aircraft still leaves vulnerabilities tied to cargo assessments. TSA currently requires unvetted shippers to use all-cargo airplanes for their cargo. The TSA is considering a pilot program to allow suspicious cargo to travel on passenger airplanes in hardened cargo containers. The 108th Congress passed legislation related to aviation security, including the Vision 100 - Century of Aviation Reauthorization Act and the National Intelligence Reform Act in response to the 9/11 Commission's recommendations. Vision 100 mandated a study on aviation security effectiveness by the Department of Homeland Security, including recommendations for improvement and the creation of the Aviation Security Capital Fund with annual appropriations of up to $500 million. The act also granted the Undersecretary for Border and Transportation Security the authority to issue grants for integrating baggage explosive detection systems at airports.
